t: Habakkuk 3
God’s Deliverance of His People
A*p prayer of Habakkuk the prophet, according to Shigionoth.
Lord,*spn I have heard the report about You and*i I fear. O*ln Lord,*s revive Your work in the midst of the years, In*ln the midst of the years make it known; In*ln wrath remember mercy.
God*ln comes from Teman, And*ln the Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah. His*ln splendor covers the heavens, And*ln the earth is full of His praise.
His*iln radiance is like the sunlight; He*ln has rays flashing*i from His hand, And*ln there is the hiding of His power.
Before*ln Him goes pestilence, And*ln plague comes after Him.
He*ln stood and surveyed the earth; He*ln looked and startled the nations. Yes,*ln the perpetual mountains were shattered, The*ln ancient hills collapsed. His*ln ways are everlasting.
I*ln saw the tents of Cushan under distress, The*ln tent curtains of the land of Midian were trembling.
Did*ln the Lord*s rage against the rivers, Or*ln was*i Your anger against the rivers, Or*ln was*i Your wrath against the sea, That*ln You rode on Your horses, On*ln Your chariots of salvation?
Your*ln bow was made bare, The*ln rods of chastisement were sworn. Selah. You*ln cleaved the earth with rivers.
The*ln mountains saw You and*i quaked; The*ln downpour of waters swept by. The*ln deep uttered forth its voice, It*ln lifted high its hands.
Sun*ln and*i moon stood in their places; They*ln went away at the light of Your arrows, At*ln the radiance of Your gleaming spear.
In*ln indignation You marched through the earth; In*ln anger You trampled the nations.
You*ln went forth for the salvation of Your people, For*ln the salvation of Your anointed. You*ln struck the head of the house of the evil To*ln lay him open from thigh to neck. Selah.
You*ln pierced with his own spears The*ln head of his throngs. They*ln stormed in to scatter us; Their*ln exultation was*i like those Who*ln devour the oppressed in secret.
You*ln trampled on the sea with Your horses, On*ln the surge of many waters.

I*ln heard and my inward parts trembled, At*ln the sound my lips quivered. Decay*ln enters my bones, And*ln in my place I tremble. Because*ln I must wait quietly for the day of distress, For*ln the people to arise who*i will invade us.

Though*ln the fig tree should not blossom And*ln there be no fruit on the vines, Though*iln the yield of the olive should fail And*ln the fields produce no food, Though*ln the flock should be cut off from the fold And*ln there be no cattle in the stalls,
Yet*ln I will exult in the Lord,*s I*ln will rejoice in the God of my salvation.
The*ln Lord God*s is my strength, And*ln He has made my feet like hinds’ feet,*i And*ln makes me walk on my high places. For*p the choir director, on my stringed instruments.
